title: The Hydrostatic Equation
content: Hydrostatic pressure is the pressure exerted by a column of fluid at rest. It's the foundation of all well control—if you don't understand this, nothing else will make sense. The formula is simple but critical: Hydrostatic Pressure (psi) = Mud Weight (ppg) × 0.052 × True Vertical Depth (ft). The constant 0.052 converts ppg to psi/ft. Remember: we always use TVD, not measured depth, because pressure depends on vertical height, not the path the wellbore takes.

variables.P: Hydrostatic pressure in pounds per square inch
variables.MW: Mud weight in pounds per gallon

mcq.question: A well has a mud weight of 10.5 ppg and a TVD of 8,000 ft. What is the hydrostatic pressure at the bottom of the hole?
mcq.explanation: P = 10.5 × 0.052 × 8,000 = 4,368 psi. This is a direct application of the hydrostatic equation. Always multiply MW × 0.052 × TVD.

openQuestions: Why do we use TVD instead of measured depth in hydrostatic calculations?
